definitions.definition: used in questions to ask for particular information about somebody/something

examples.text: What is your name?
What *(= what job)* does he do?
What time is it?
What kind of music do you like?

definitions.definition: the thing or things that; whatever

examples.text: What you need is a good meal.
Nobody knows what will happen next.
I spent what little time I had with my family.

definitions.definition: used to say that you think that something is especially good, bad, etc.

examples.text: What awful weather!
What a beautiful house!

definitions.definition: and other things of the same type

examples.text: It's full of old toys, books and what not.

definitions.definition: despite any problems or difficulties you may have

examples.text: He promised to support her come what may.

definitions.definition: to be punished/punish somebody severely

examples.text: I'll give her what for if she does that again.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize your opinion

examples.text: Is he stupid or what?

definitions.definition: used when you are not sure about something

examples.text: I don't know if he's a teacher or what.
Are we going now or what?

definitions.definition: used to express surprise at what somebody has just said

examples.text: ‘He's getting married.’ ‘Say what?’

definitions.definition: used to show that you think something is not important, especially after somebody has criticized you for it

examples.text: ‘He's fifteen years younger than you!’ ‘So what?’
So what if nobody else agrees with me?

definitions.definition: used when you have not heard or have not understood something

examples.text: What? I can't hear you.

definitions.definition: used to show that you have heard somebody and to ask what they want

examples.text: ‘Mummy!’ ‘What?’ ‘I'm thirsty.’

definitions.definition: used to express surprise or anger

examples.text: ‘It will cost $500.’ ‘What?’
‘I asked her to marry me.’ ‘**You what?**’

definitions.definition: used to make a suggestion

examples.text: What about a trip to France?

definitions.definition: used to introduce somebody/something into the conversation

examples.text: What about you, Joe? Do you like football?

definitions.definition: used instead of a name that you cannot remember

examples.text: She's just gone out with old what-d'you-call-him.

definitions.definition: for what purpose or reason?

examples.text: What is this tool for?
What did you do that for *(= why did you do that)*?
‘I need to see a doctor.’ ‘What for?’

definitions.definition: what would happen if?

examples.text: What if the train is late?
What if she forgets to bring it?

definitions.definition: used when admitting that something is true, to ask why it should be considered important

examples.text: Yes, I wrote the article. What of it?

definitions.definition: used to suggest that something you have heard is a stupid idea or does not make sense

examples.text: They dropped their best player. What's all that about?

definitions.definition: (know) what things are useful, important, etc.

examples.text: She certainly knows what's what.

definitions.definition: used to ask why somebody is behaving in a strange way

examples.text: What's with you? You haven't said a word all morning.

definitions.definition: used to ask the reason for something

examples.text: What's with all this walking? Can't we take a cab?

definitions.definition: used to list the various reasons for something

examples.text: What with the cold weather and my bad leg, I haven't been out for weeks.

wordOrigin: Old English hwæt, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wat and German was, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin quod.
